text: So, what was is, or he is, she is, it is?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We can use this with some other convertible words as well to make sentences.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Another rule for these convertible words is that words in English that end A-N-T or E-N-T, most of them we can just stick an E on the end and they become Spanish.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, for example, IMPORTANT becomes IMPORTANTE, IMPORTANTE.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: The stress is as much part of the word as the sounds, which is why we want to get into the habit of just processing where is the accent, not trying to memorise it, just looking where it is, not trying to memorise it, just observing it.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, how would you say it is important?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you say it is constant?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: If you add on MENTE, MENTE, this sound, you get LI in English.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: If you want to say constantly, you can say CONSTANTEMENTE.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, how would you say legally?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How do you think you say real in Spanish?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: When we have an R at the beginning, you might hear it like a rolling R.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How do you think you would say really?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: REAL also means royal, like Real Madrid is not, you know, real Madrid.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, what would it mean if I said to you NORMALMENTE ES IMPORTANTE.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Normally as in usually, it's important.
speaker: Speaker 2

text: You actually use normally like usually.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now, if we have a J sound, a J sound in a convertible word.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, we're not working with the letter G, we're working with the sound here.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: If we have a J sound in a convertible word, this J is going to become J in Spanish.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now, if you know how to say Argentina, for example, in Spanish.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: If you've heard that anywhere, this is a good hook to remember this rule.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: If we have a J sound, it's going to become J as a sound.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, this doesn't mean any G.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: For example, how would you say GLOBAL?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, it's not a G, it's the J sound.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, we're causing a bit of friction in the word GENERAL.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, NATURALMENTE, you can also use it a little bit like OBVIOUSLY, something like that.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, words ending IBLY or ABLY, we can also convert many of them.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We just have to pronounce the syllable by syllable and put the accent second from the end.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, you can't do this like if you say DOABLE, for example.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You know, it's when ABLY or IBLY is really part of the word, you will probably be able to do this.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Some of these rules are more useful than others.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Some of these rules have more exceptions than others.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We want to just get in the habit of identifying them and then getting this sense of what words in English are from Latin and which ones we can experiment with converting over to Spanish.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now, this gives us over 3,000 words and there are enough words to be very conversational.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, we want to feel free to experiment with the vocabulary, but at the same time, we don't want to feel restricted by the fact that we might find an exception or we might use one that doesn't work.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And feeling comfortable about that possibility of making that error is what really allows you to learn quickly because with this experimentation, you find very quickly the words that you can use.
speaker: Speaker 1
